data.Meaning:
Noun. Terror, the frights, nerves. Often heard as the screaming 
        abdabs. Also very occasionally 'habdabs'. [1940s]
Verb. To wash oneself. E.g."She's in the bathroom abluting." {Informal}
Adv. Absolutely.
Exclam. Goodbye! A jocular and intentional mispronunciation of "I'll be seeing you!
Noun. An act of incontinence, especially in children. E.g."Stop the car at the next services, Lucy's had an accident." {Informal}
Phrs. Seemingly accidental but with veiled malice or harm.
Adj. Bisexual.

Adj. Excellent, wonderful. 
        Exclam. Excellent!
Noun. The drug LSD. Lysergic acid diethylamide. [Orig. U.S. 1960s]
Noun. Money. From the Egyptian akka.
Noun. A man who considered strong, active and brave, who generally participates in macho activities.
Verb. Believe. Cockney rhyming slang. E.g."I don't Adam and Eve it, it's not true!
Noun. Water.

Adj. Socially unfashionable or awkward but likeable and appealing. A combination of the words 'dork' and adorable. Expression popularized in the U.K. by titular book by Sarra Manning. [Orig. U.S. Late 1990s]
Noun. An advertisement. {Informal}
Adj. Over-excited. Becoming obsolete, although still heard used by older generations. Also as aeriated.

Noun. 1. Any course after the mains during a meal, such as dessert, pudding, cake, etc. {Informal} 
      2. In sport, frequently football, a confrontation between players after a foul or incident. E.g."I'm not surprised he's gone in for some afters, that foul could have broken his leg." {Informal}
Noun. Afternoon. [North-west use]
Noun. Afternoon. E.g."Are you going to watch the game this afty?" [North-west use]
Noun. Aggressive troublemaking, violence, aggression. Abb. of aggravation.
Adj. Annoyed, irritated, aggitated. Abb. of aggravated. E.g."My mum's getting a bit aggy because my brother won't tidy his bedroom.
Adj.  Clumsy, unsophisticated, especially in a sporting context. E.g."That was a very agricultural tackle by the defender, but it did the job and saved a sure goal." {Informal}
Noun.  A woman who, in response to reader's letters, provides advice on personal and relationship problems via a newspaper or magazine column. Rarely, also agony uncle. {Informal}
Noun. An expulsion of air from the anus, a fart. See 'float an air biscuit'. [Orig. U.S.]
Noun. A stupid person. [Orig. U.S.]
Adj. Drunk, intoxicated. [N. Ireland use]
Adj. Lacking in strength, insubstantial, vague. {Informal}
Noun. An imaginary guitar played by rock music fans whilst listening to their favourite tunes.
Verb. To ask. E.g."I aksed him to move his car from the driveway." [dialect]
Noun. Knickers, underwear. Rhyming slang, often shortened to Alans. Alan Whicker was a popular British journalist and TV presenter from the 1950s through to the turn of the century.
Noun. Sweet, ready-mixed fruit drinks containing alcohol. A combination of the words alcohol and 'pop' (noun 1). Cf. 'tart fuel'. {Informal}
Adj. Drunk, intoxicated by alcohol, usually beer (ale).
Noun. An alcoholic. Also as alky.
Phrs. Lacking manual dexterity, clumsy. E.g."Can you help me thread that needle? I'm all fingers and thumbs." {Informal}
Phrs. Of a woman, having a superficial appearance with no real substance beneath. Derog.
Noun. All the fixtures and fittings necessary and expected. An abb. of all modern conveniences. {Informal}
Phrs. Boastful and without just reason. E.g."You shouldn't pay any attention to him, he's all mouth and no trousers.
Noun. A club night or entertainment event that lasts all night. {Informal}
Phrs. Disorganized, chaotic, confused, in disarray. E.g."I was all over the place; I'd had half a dozen a pints and couldnt string a sentence together." {Informal}

Phrs. 1. In a mess, out of order, disorganized. 
        2. Everywhere. E.g."I've been all over the shop this morning and I can't find her anywhere.
Verb. Forget it, don't bother. [Orig Black/ London use]
Noun. The vagina. Abb. of all quiet on the Western front,  rhyming slang on 'cunt'.
Noun. A public house, a bar. Rhyming slang on 'boozer'.
Phrs. Messed up, useless, in ruin, out of order, in a bad condition.
Phrs. Messed up, in disarray. E.g."Our whole holiday went all to pot when Dad got arrested for being drunk.
Noun. Socks. Cockney rhyming slang, often shortened to almonds.
Exclam. Hello. A greeting. No answer is expected to what is inherently a question. Northern dialect has created the phonetic corruption alreet which sounds more like awreet.
Adj. Amazing, very impressive. Also used as as exclamation.
Noun. Lager. [Orig. Aust.]
Noun. Brakes. Also put the anchors on something. E.g."I slammed on the anchors and hit my head on the steering wheel.
Noun. The Royal Navy.
Noun. Abb. of anus.
Noun. Children, particularly crawling babies. [Orig. Aust.]

Noun. An often socially inept person, having an obsessive interest in a hobby or subject. Usually has little or no fashion sense, and errs towards eccentricity. Originates from the 'trainspotter' look, of wearing anoraks; spending so much time at the end of station platforms in all weather necessitates the wearing of such attire. Derog. Cf. 'trainspotter'.

Phrs. If anyone has any ideas, or a response, to the question/problem that has just been posed, please let me know? From when, during the 1970s and 80s, blank postcards were used by viewers to mail answers to competition questions posed on TV programmes, in the hope of winning a prize. The advent of SMS and phonelines ensured the end of the  postcards as a means of entering competitions.
Adj. Nervous, agitated, restless.
Adj. Old fashioned. Possibly from antique(y) or antiquated. E.g."I'm not wearing those shoes, they're so antwacky and something my gran might wear." [Merseyside/West Lancashire use]
Phrs. Of value, of any worth. E.g."Have you heard their new CD? I heard it was atrocious but do you think it's any cop?" See 'cop' (adj). Cf. 'no cop'.
Adv. Anyway. Also spelt anyroad. [Northern use]
Crazy, beserk, furious. See 'go ape/apeshit'.
Noun. A pet name for a silly person. A shortening of daft apeth. Apeth, derived from haypneeworth (half a penny's worth) but pronounced ha'p'orth.
Noun. 20. Cockney rhyming slang on 'score'. [1950s]
Noun. Stairs. Possibly the most commonly expressed piece of Cockney rhyming slang that is used as an example of such, or used in jocular mimicry.
Noun. Bottom, buttocks, 'arse'. Rhyming slang from April in Paris rhyming with 'arris'.

Noun. �2000. From the amount of money given by Jeffrey Archer to a prostitute (Monica Coughlan) to enable her to leave the country, and in order to buy her silence over services rendered. Jeffrey Archer, ex-member of Parliament and best selling author, served a prison sentence for perjury and perverting the course of justice.

data.Meaning: Phrs. Rhetorical, confrontational question to a person who is considered to be talking nonsense of too much.

Noun. Buttocks, 'arse'. Convoluted Cockney rhyming slang for 'arse'; Arris, an abbreviation of Aristotle, rhyming with bottle, and thereafter leading to bottle and glass rhyming with 'arse'. Also spelt aris.

        2. An objectionable person.
        3. A mistake, a poor job. E.g."He's made such an arse of that plastering job that I think we'll need to redo it."

        2. A bother, trouble. E.g."It's an arse-ache having to mow the lawn every week. Why can't we just pave over the garden?

Noun. 1. An ugly person.

        Noun. An act of sycophantic behaviour. E.g."If he keeps giving the boss an arse licking at the rate he's currently doing, then he'll be first in line for a promotion.
Noun. In large quantities, a lot of, a great amount. E.g." She's given me arse loads of paperwork to complete before lunch.

Noun. 1. A contemptible person. Also arse monger.

[1990s]

data.Slang: bent as a bottle of chips
data.Meaning:
Phrs. 1. Homosexual.
        2. Crooked, dishonest. See 'bottle of chips'.

data.Slang: bent as a nine bob note
data.Meaning:
Phrs. 1. Homosexual. See 'bent'.
        2. Crooked, dishonest. 
        A catch-phrase whose original meaning was version 2, but with the onset of 'bent' referring to homosexually has come to be heard more with regard to version 1. In British currency, a bob was a slang expression for a shilling (five pence) but with decimalization in 1971 became obsolete. There was never any such thing as a nine bob note, hence the simile. Cf. 'queer as a nine bob note' and 'camp as a row of tents'.

data.Slang: bent as a nine pound note
data.Meaning:
Phrs. A modern variation on 'bent as a nine bob 
        note', see above.

Noun. An idiot, objectionable person. Derived from the rhyming slang Berkshire Hunt or Berkeley Hunt, meaning 'cunt'. Normally Berkshire and Berkeley would be pronounced Barkshire and Barkeley. This expression is generally accepted as inoffensive despite its origins and meaning. Also as 'burk'.

The expression, if not invented, was popularized by John Sitton,  manager of Leyton Orient football club, who, on a 1995 TV documentary on his team ('Orient: Club for a Fiver'), angrily berates his team during the half-time team talk, after going 3-0 down. [1990s]

Noun. A woman or women. A male expression for females viewed sexually. Also abbreviated to 'skirt'. Derog.

Noun. A euphemism for the genitals.

Noun. Oral sex. An abb. of 'blow job'.
Noun. A person who reveals too much in conversation, a gossip.

Phrs. Very black.

Adj./Adv.  Blatantly, blatant.

Noun. Mechanical lubricating oil. [Mainly Crewe use]

Exclam. An exclamation of surprise.

Noun. Unnattractive, when in phrases such as having a face like a blind cobbler's thumb.
Noun. An excellent achievement. E.g."Tim's played another blinder." {Informal}
Adj. Excellent, wonderful. E.g."We had a blinding time last night.

Noun. 1. Jewellery. There's been much speculation as to its origins, including amongst those suggestions put forward are the following:
        �� From either the sound of jewellery knocking against jewellery.
        �� The sound of cash registers when a sale is made.
        �� The written sound in cartoons when light catches and reflects off jewellery. 
        What does appear to be acknowledged is that the expression was popularized by U.S. rapper B.G. (aka Baby Gangsta) in 1999. [Orig. Black U.S.]
        2. Obvious and appealing wealth, by extension of meaning 1.

Exclam. An old fashioned inoffensive exclamation of surprise, often expressed without the 'g' and 'h', so blinkin' 'eck. Also 'heck' can be replaced with 'hell', so blinking hell.

Adj. 1. An intensifier such as 'bloody'. E.g."How can I have toast when that blithering idiot has just eaten all the bread!"

Verb. To talk incessently and boringly. E.g."Please stop blithering on, your voice is driving my crazy." {Informal}

Noun. A man.

Noun. A friendly term of address. Orig. Black use for addressing a fellow Black.

Noun. A contemptible, objectionable person, and frequently used as a term of abuse. From blood cloth, a woman's sanitary towel. Also as bloodclart, bloodclaht, bloodclot, bludclat, bludclart, bloodklaat, bloodklatt amongst other spelling variations. [Orig. W.I., Mainly Black use]
Noun. Sexual acts with a woman during the period of her menstruation.

Adj. Expressing annoyance as an intensifier. E.g."That bloody idiot needs a good thumping."

Exclam. An exclamation of surprise or frustration.
Exclam. An exclamation of surprise or anger. Cf. 'flaming Nora!' and 'ruddy-Nora!'
Noun. A mistake. {Informal}

Verb. To kick a ball forcefully, often implying without good control. [Scottish use]
Adj. Drunk. [Scottish use]
Adj. Very drunk. [Early 1900s]

Noun. Cannabis or marijuana. It's interesting to note that in

Vrb phrs. To be very angry. E.g."If you don't calm down you'll blow a gasket and embarrass yourself.

Verb. 1. To kill.

Noun. A method of sharing a 'joint' between two people, with

Verb. To vomit. E.g."" Suzanne's been blowing chunks

Exclam. A dismissive exclamation of frustration and anger.
Noun. Fellatio or cunnilingus. [Orig. U.S.]

      [1960s]
